long_desc.thetext:
Description of problem: /etc/ld.so.conf.d/tclx-x86_64.conf (or %{_sysconfig}/ld.so.conf.d/tclx-x86_64.conf if you prefer) contains one line, which should be the path to the tclx libraries. But that path is currently /usr/lib64/tcl8.6/tclx8.4 (on 64-bit), while the file contents read "/usr/lib64/tcl8.5/tclx8.4" (note the tcl version in the path, not the tclx).
Version-Release number of selected component (if applicable): tclx-8.4.0-26.fc24
How reproducible: any time
Steps to Reproduce: 1. ls -d /usr/lib(64)/tcl8.6/tclx8.4 or rpm -ql tclx 2. cat /etc/ld.so.conf/tclx*.conf
Actual results: /usr/lib64/tcl8.6/tclx8.4 in one, /usr/lib64/tcl8.5/tclx8.4 in the other
Expected results: contents match
Additional info: I don't really grok dynamic linking yet, so I have no idea how this would impact programs using the library. If it hasn't been reported over the span of an entire release (the FC25 package still has fc24 in %{dist}), does ldconfig actually do anything? Beats me.
Thanks for the report, it's apparently bug. The TCL version was hardcoded. IMHO it can work if consumers use e.g. RPATH.
